selection_rationale: With many clients and sparse participation, client_frac directly controls the number of contributors per round and the communication budget; subspace_frac (r/D) dictates SFedAvg’s expressivity vs. communication and can accelerate convergence with fewer transmitted parameters; momentum (mu) smooths aggregation across rounds when per-round signal is weak and noisy due to low participation.

configs.rationale: Halve participation to reduce communication; keep baseline subspace and momentum to test accuracy-per-comm trade-off.
Aggressive communication reduction via smaller subspace; higher momentum to stabilize updates with fewer directions and clients.
Baseline participation with reduced subspace and stronger momentum to improve efficiency while preserving accuracy.
Increase expressivity to accelerate convergence at low participation; test if larger subspace improves early accuracy.
More clients per round to reduce variance; baseline subspace to gauge convergence speed vs. communication increase.
Higher participation with leaner subspace and stronger momentum for improved accuracy-per-communication.
Lower momentum to test reduced accumulation under sparse participation, checking stability vs. speed.

expected_improvement: We expect moderate to higher momentum (mu≈0.95) and smaller subspace (r/D≈0.05–0.10) to improve accuracy-per-communication under low participation; increasing client_frac to 0.20 should stabilize and slightly boost accuracy at the cost of more communication, while larger subspace (≈0.20) may speed early rounds but with higher bandwidth.
